choices.text: Meckel's diverticulum
Duodenal atresia
Hirschsprung's disease
Intussusception

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-month-old infant with complaints of sudden onset of intermittent, severe abdominal pain and bilious vomiting. The infant draws their legs up to their abdomen and cries loudly when the pain is present. On physical examination, there is a palpable sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. An abdominal x-ray reveals air-fluid levels and an USG revealed a target or bulls eye sign. What is the likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario and the radiographical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intussusception

 

Option D:

 

Intussusception – telescoping of a proximal segment of the intestine (intussusceptum) into a distal segment (intussuscipiens).

 

Occurs most often near the ileocecal junction (ileocolic intussusception)

 

The majority of cases in children are idiopathic.

 

Classic triad (<15% of cases)

 

  • Intermittent colicky abdominal pain
  • Sausage shaped abdominal mass
  • Red currant jelly stool is seen in less than 15% of patients at the time of presentation.
  • Occasionally, the initial presenting sign is lethargy or altered consciousness alone, without pain, rectal bleeding, or other symptoms that suggest an intra-abdominal process and is often confused with sepsis.

 

Clinical Manifestations

 

Patients with intussusception typically develop the sudden onset of intermittent, severe, crampy, progressive abdominal pain, accompanied by inconsolable crying and drawing up of the legs toward the abdomen.

 

  • Between symptoms child will be playing and doing normal activity. → Vomiting Later → Continuous abdominal pain
  • The stool may contains gross or occult blood or be a mixture of blood and mucous and sloughing mucosa, giving it the appearance of currant jelly.
  • Lethargy - Palpable abdominal mass.
  • Physical - A sausage shaped abdominal mass. - Abdominal distension and Dehydration.

 

Diagnosis

 

Ultrasonography - A Doughnut or ‘target sign’ is seen, representing layers of the intestine within the intestine.

 

Treatment - Stabilize and resuscitate with intravenous fluids Hydration, electrolyte, acid-base balance.

 

  • uncomplicated reduced with air enema 24-48 hrs
  • Non-operative reduction using hydrostatic or pneumatic pressure by enema
  • Risk of perforation – adv in pneumatic technique.
  • Surgical treatment -Indicated for patients with peritonitis or evidence of perforation or in whom non-operative reduction is unsuccessful.
  • Manual reduction at operation is attempted

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: It can cause pain and bleeding but is less likely to present with a palpable abdominal mass and the "bull's-eye" sign on ultrasound.

 

Option B. Duodenal atresia: Presents with early-onset vomiting, typically in neonates, and is associated with a "double bubble" sign on X-ray, not the findings described.

 

Option C. Hirschsprung's disease: Characterized by chronic constipation and abdominal distension due to a lack of enteric nervous system cells in the distal colon; it does not typically present acutely with a palpable mass and "bull's-eye" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic presentation and ultrasound findings of intussusception in infants, which include sudden, intermittent abdominal pain, bilious vomiting, a palpable sausage-shaped mass, and the "bull's-eye" sign on imaging. Early identification and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as bowel necrosis.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1812-1814.

choices.text: Celiac disease is most commonly confused with IBS
10% of adults with iron deficiency anemia have undiagnosed celiac disease
On histology Increase in thickness of the mucosa

questions.text: A child exhibiting HLA-DQ8 positivity presents with chronic diarrhea, fatigue, pallor, and failure to thrive. To confirm the diagnosis, a biopsy is conducted, revealing crypt hyperplasia and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, leading to a diagnosis of celiac disease. Considering what is known about celiac disease, which of the following statements is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) On histology Increase in thickness of the mucosa

 

Option C:

 

The hallmark histological features of celiac disease include crypt hyperplasia, increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, and villous atrophy, not an increase in the thickness of the mucosa. In fact, the mucosal damage in celiac disease typically leads to villous atrophy and thinning of the mucosa, which contributes to malabsorption and the symptoms associated with the disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Misdiagnosis as IBS: It is true that celiac disease can be confused with IBS due to overlapping gastrointestinal symptoms, making this statement correct.

 

Option B. Iron deficiency anemia: It is also true that a significant proportion of adults with iron deficiency anemia may have undiagnosed celiac disease, as celiac disease can lead to malabsorption of nutrients, including iron.

 

Option D. Non-responsive celiac disease: Celiac disease that does not respond to a strict gluten-free diet, known as refractory celiac disease, does indeed have a poorer prognosis and may require further medical intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological hallmark of celiac disease involves villous atrophy and not an increase in mucosal thickness.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 387- Page No 8386.

A. Most common cause of vomiting in children: Aerophagia (3), which is the excessive swallowing of air, often during feeding or due to rapid eating, can lead to vomiting in children.

 

B. Most common cause of constipation in children: Habitual or functional constipation (4) is the most frequent cause, often due to withholding behavior or insufficient intake of fiber and fluids.

 

C. Most common cause of portal hypertension in children: Extrahepatic portal vein obstruction (EHPVO) (2) is a significant cause of portal hypertension in the pediatric population, often leading to complications such as variceal bleeding.

choices.text: Rhino virus.
Rota virus.
Noro virus
Zika virus

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought in by their mother due to acute onset watery diarrhea, having experienced six episodes in the past 24 hours. The child presents without fever, abdominal pain, or vomiting and appears alert and well-hydrated. Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen. Considering the clinical presentation, what is the most common infectious cause of diarrhea in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rota virus.

 

Option B:

 

Rotavirus is recognized as the leading cause of acute viral gastroenteritis among children worldwide, particularly affecting those under the age of 5. It primarily presents with symptoms of watery diarrhea, which can lead to severe dehydration in some cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rhinovirus: Primarily associated with the common cold, rhinovirus mainly affects the respiratory system, causing symptoms like runny nose, sore throat, and cough, rather than gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.

 

Option C. Norovirus: While norovirus is a common cause of gastroenteritis and can lead to outbreaks, especially in semi-closed environments such as schools and cruise ships, it is not as commonly associated with acute gastroenteritis in children as rotavirus. Norovirus tends to affect people of all ages and is characterized by sudden onset of vomiting and watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Zika virus: Known for its association with outbreaks in tropical regions and its link to birth defects when infections occur during pregnancy, Zika virus is primarily transmitted by mosquitoes and does not commonly cause diarrhea as a primary symptom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotavirus is the most common cause of acute gastroenteritis in children, characterized by watery diarrhea.
  • Rhino virus is the most common cause of upper respiratory tract infection in children
  • Noro virus is the most common cause of diarrhoea in adults
  • Zika virus will results in microcephaly.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 292 Page No- 7022.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric department due to experiencing five episodes of loose stools. Upon examination, the child shows a keen interest in drinking water and has normal skin turgor. Following WHO guidelines, you initiate Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) therapy and counsel the mother accordingly. What is the recommended dosage of zinc supplementation for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10 mg for 10-14 days.

 

Explanation:

 

For infants and children with acute diarrhea, the WHO recommends zinc supplementation as part of the management. The recommended dosage for infants under 6 months of age is 10 mg of zinc per day for 10-14 days. Zinc supplementation during diarrhea episodes has been shown to reduce the duration and severity of the episode and may also have a prophylactic effect against future episodes for 2-3 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The dosage of Zinc given in the child is

<6 months of age – 10 mg/day.

>6 months of age – 20 mg/day.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1854-1874.

choices.text: Primary Lactose Intolerance
Secondary Lactose Intolerance
Tertiary Lactose Intolerance
Both primary and secondary Lactose Intolerance

questions.text: A concerned mother brings her 5-month-old infant to the clinic due to three episodes of vomiting and diarrhea over the past three days. Examination reveals a perianal rash and the presence of acidic stools. The mother shares that she recently returned to work and began substituting breast milk with cow's milk. You advise her on the benefits of expressing and storing breast milk for feeding. Considering the clinical presentation and history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary Lactose Intolerance

 

Option B:

 

Secondary lactose intolerance is most likely in this case, where the introduction of cow's milk has potentially irritated the infant's digestive system, leading to inflammation and temporary reduction in lactase enzyme activity. This condition is often triggered by a change in diet or after gastrointestinal infections, leading to difficulty in digesting lactose, the sugar found in milk, resulting in symptoms like diarrhea and vomiting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Primary Lactose Intolerance: Rare in infants, it's a genetic condition where babies are born with low levels of lactase enzyme. Symptoms would likely have appeared earlier if this were the case.

 

Option C. Cow's Milk Protein Allergy: While similar in presentation, the immediate onset of symptoms after introducing cow's milk suggests intolerance to lactose rather than an allergic reaction to milk proteins.

 

Option D. Gastroenteritis: Typically associated with infectious agents, it could present with vomiting and diarrhea but less likely to be directly linked to the introduction of cow's milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactose intolerance can either be primary (lactase activity that gradually declines with aging) or secondary (an infection or enteropathy damages the villi, resulting in lactose intolerance).

 

Many patients who have lactose intolerance diagnosed can tolerate Yoghurt.

 

Other products, such as whole or skim milk, ice cream, or buttermilk, have more lactose (approximately 10 g/serving) and are less likely to be tolerated.

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1854-1874. O P Ghai – Page No-293

choices.text: Immediate Tracheoscopic removal.
Immediate Esophagoscopic removal.
Wait and Watch
Immediate Laryngoscopic removal.

questions.text: A mother presents her 6-year-old son to the clinic, reporting dysphagia. Upon examination, the child shows no signs of respiratory distress. A chest X-ray reveals radiopaque findings suggestive of a foreign body aspiration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wait and Watch

 

Option C:

 

In cases where foreign body aspiration is suspected but the patient is stable with no respiratory distress, the initial management approach is often conservative. This involves observation and monitoring for any development of symptoms or signs of airway compromise. Immediate attempts at removal without clear evidence of airway obstruction can potentially lead to complications, especially in cases where the foreign body is lodged without causing immediate symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Immediate Tracheoscopic removal: Tracheoscopic removal is indicated if there are signs of severe airway obstruction or respiratory distress. However, in stable patients without such signs, immediate intervention may not be necessary.

 

Option B. Immediate Esophagoscopic removal: Esophagoscopic removal is appropriate if the foreign body is confirmed to be lodged in the esophagus and causing symptoms. However, if the location is uncertain or if the patient is asymptomatic, immediate intervention may not be warranted.

 

Option D. Immediate Laryngoscopic removal: Laryngoscopic removal is indicated if the foreign body is visible in the larynx or upper airway and causing significant obstruction. However, if there are no signs of upper airway compromise, immediate intervention may not be required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Foreign body in the esophagus - Since it doesn’t produce any major symptoms and it will dislodge into stomach and will be removed out itself. So, the best management is to wait and watch.

 

In case of Coin in the trachea immediate removal is advised.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 360Page No 7818-7821.

questions.text: A mother rushes her 2-year-old child to the emergency department, concerned about severe dehydration. Upon examination, the child appears lethargic and weak. The healthcare provider notices several physical signs. Which of the following features is least likely to be observed in cases of severe dehydration?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Drinks Eagerly on offering water

 

Option D:

 

In severe dehydration, the body experiences significant fluid loss, leading to electrolyte imbalance and characteristic physical signs. Very sunken eyes (option A), slow skin recoil after a skin pinch test indicating decreased skin turgor (option B), and very dry buccal mucosa (option C) are classic features of severe dehydration due to the loss of fluid volume. However, it’s important to note that in cases of severe dehydration, children often appear lethargic and weak, which impairs their ability to drink eagerly even if offered water. This response is due to the body’s compromised state and altered mental status, making option D the least likely observation in cases of severe dehydration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Very sunken eyes: This is a typical sign of severe dehydration due to decreased fluid volume.

 

Option B. Skin goes back slowly after a skin pinch test: Also characteristic of severe dehydration, indicating decreased skin turgor.

 

Option C. Very dry buccal mucosa: Another hallmark sign of severe dehydration due to decreased saliva production and fluid loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In case of severe dehydration, the child will be unable to drink the offered water.

 

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 1854-1874.

questions.text: A mother brings her child with a history of episodes of loose stools for 1 day along with features of irritability and restlessness. There is no history of fever or blood in stools. On examination, the child's eyes are sunken, and skin pinch goes back slowly within 2 seconds. On giving water, the child accepts and drinks readily. What will be the best management for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give Zinc supplementation and ORS only and ask mother to come back if there is development of any danger signs.

 

Option B:

 

Based on the clinical presentation of the child with a short duration of loose stools, signs of dehydration (sunken eyes, delayed skin pinch test), and acceptance of oral fluids, the child likely has moderate dehydration. In such cases, the initial management consists of oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with oral rehydration salts (ORS) along with zinc supplementation. Intravenous fluids are usually reserved for cases of severe dehydration or if the child cannot tolerate oral fluids. Starting oral antibiotics is not indicated in the absence of specific indications like dysentery or severe illness.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Start intravenous fluids immediately and immediately refer to a higher center: Intravenous fluids are typically reserved for cases of severe dehydration or if the child cannot tolerate oral fluids. Immediate referral to a higher center may not be necessary if the child responds well to oral rehydration therapy.

 

Option C. Administer intravenous antibiotics and immediately refer to a higher center: Antibiotics are not indicated in uncomplicated cases of acute diarrhea without specific indications such as dysentery. Immediate referral may not be necessary unless there are signs of severe illness or complications.

 

Option D. Start oral antibiotics and send the child home: Antibiotics are not routinely recommended for the management of acute diarrhea unless specific bacterial etiology like dysentery is suspected. Starting oral antibiotics without proper indication can contribute to antibiotic resistance and is not appropriate in this scenario.

choices.text: ORS with antibiotics
ORS only
ORS with low-lactose diet
ORS with low-lactose diet and probiotics

questions.text: A mother brings her 1-year-old infant with a history of 10–12 episodes of watery stools per day for the last 2 days. Recognizing the severity of the condition, you decide to initiate zinc supplementation along with additional measures to manage the diarrhea effectively. Considering the comprehensive approach to management, what else should be prescribed to the 1-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ORS only

 

Option B:

 

In a case of infant with episodes of loose stools, treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation and continued breastfeeding.

 

Zinc Supplementation is helpful in decreasing severity & duration of diarrhea and also risk of persistent diarrhea.

 

Zinc is recommended to be supplemented as sulphate, acetate or gluconate formulation, at a dose of 20 mg of elemental zinc per day for children >6 months for a period of 14 days

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ORS with antibiotics: Antibiotics are not routinely recommended for acute watery diarrhea unless there is evidence of bacterial infection or specific indications for antibiotic therapy.

 

Option C. ORS with low-lactose diet: While a low-lactose diet may be beneficial in cases of lactose intolerance, it is not the primary intervention for managing acute diarrhea, especially in the initial stages of treatment.

 

Option D. ORS with low-lactose diet and probiotics: While these interventions may have potential benefits, they are not the initial management priority in acute diarrhea, which requires prompt rehydration with ORS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In managing acute diarrhea in infants, oral rehydration solution (ORS) plays a central role in restoring hydration and electrolyte balance, which are essential for recovery. ORS contains the optimal balance of electrolytes and glucose to replace fluid losses due to diarrhea and prevent dehydration. It is the cornerstone of treatment recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) for managing acute diarrhea in children.

 

While zinc supplementation, low-lactose diet, and probiotics can be beneficial in certain cases, the initial management priority is to ensure adequate rehydration with ORS. Antibiotics are not routinely indicated in cases of acute watery diarrhea unless there is evidence of bacterial etiology or severe illness requiring targeted treatment. A low-lactose diet and probiotics may be considered in cases of lactose intolerance or persistent diarrhea, but they do not replace the primary role of ORS in managing acute diarrhea.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 8th Edition, Page No-290-295.

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-year-old baby Somu to a pediatrician with a history of multiple episodes of loose, watery stools for 2 days. His mother mentions that he has been restless and irritated since yesterday. However, he can drink water when offered. Physical examination reveals an irritated and thirsty baby with a heart rate of 140/min and a respiratory rate of 39/min. The pediatrician pinches the abdominal skin, which returns within 2 seconds. Based on the history and physical examination findings, which of the following is the best management plan in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plan B

 

Option D:

 

Based on the clinical history and examination findings the child has some dehydration, the next step is to treat by the Plan B.

 Treatment Plan B: Treatment of ‘Some Dehydration’

 

  • Deficit replacement or rehydration therapy is calculated as 75 mL/kg of ORS, to be given over 4 hr. If ORS cannot be taken orally then nasogastric tube can be used. If child’s weight cannot be taken then only age may be used to calculate fluid requirement as shown in table.

 

 

If after 4 hr, the child still has some dehydration then another treatment with ORS (as in rehydration therapy) is to be given. This therapy is effective in 95% cases.

 

  • Maintenance fluid therapy to replace This phase should begin when signs of dehydration disappear, usually within 4 hr. ORS should be administered in volumes equal to diarrheal losses, usually to a maximum of 10 mL/kg per stool. Breastfeeding and semisolid food are continued after replacement or deficit. Plain water can be offered in between

 

Explanation:

 

Option A - Plan A is the treatment of No dehydration.

 

Option B- Plan C is the treatment of Severe dehydration.

 

Option C- Plan D is not a recommended plan for the treatment of dehydration.

choices.text: Reassure the mother
Ask mother not to take those morning tablets
Do a TSH and T4 assay in infant.

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought in with constipation and failure to thrive. Further examination reveals an umbilical hernia, decreased muscle tone, and short stature. The mother mentions that she has been taking regular medication in the morning for an endemic illness. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this infant's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Do a TSH and T4 assay in infant.

 

Option C:

 

This is a case of endemic hypothyroidism, so to assess the presence of hypothyroidism in infant we need to do an TSH and T4 assay in infant.

 

The most common cause of hypothyroidism in endemic areas is endemic hypothyroidism because of iodine deficiency.

 

Whereas MCC of hypothyroidism in non-endemic areas is thyroid dysgenesis.

 

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism (cretinism) are:

 

  • Failure to thrive
  • Delayed development of milestones
  • Hoarse cry
  • Mottling of skin
  • Macroglossia and
  • Hypotonia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Since it’s a case of congenital hypothyroidism we should treat the infant not to Reassure.

 

Option B. Since mother is also suffering from the endemic hypothyroidism, we shouldn’t ask her to stop the tablets.

 

Option D. the cause of the short stature is hypothyroidism not the GH deficiency, there is no need of GH assay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs of congenital hypothyroidism in infants, includes constipation, failure to thrive, umbilical hernia, decreased muscle tone, and short stature, and to understand that the first step in evaluation is to check thyroid function tests, specifically TSH and T4 levels. This approach helps in early diagnosis and treatment, which is crucial for normal development.

 

Ref; Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 581 Page No- 11398-11423

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy, who has been managing a condition with the aid of a syringe and medication for the past 5 years, presents with a recent random blood sugar (RBS) value of 158 mg/dl while on medication. Intrigued by an Instagram post about his condition, he inquires about the diagnostic criteria for his illness. Which of the following is not a recognized diagnostic criterion for the disease he is likely managing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fasting blood sugar of > 150mg/dl.

 

The image shown here is the insulin. So, the child is suffering from the Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus.

 

The diagnostic criteria for DM  

 

  • Fasting blood sugar of > 126mg/dl.
  • Random blood sugar of > 200mg/dl.
  • HbA1C of >6.5%

 

Dose of glucose for OGTT in children is 1.75g/kg of ideal body weight.

 

Treatment of choice for Type 1 DM is Insulin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fasting blood sugar > 126mg/dl: This is a standard criterion for the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

Option B. Random blood sugar > 200mg/dl: A random blood sugar level exceeding 200 mg/dl, especially when accompanied by classic symptoms of diabetes, can be diagnostic.

 

Option D. HbA1C > 6.5%: An HbA1C level greater than 6.5% is a well-recognized diagnostic criterion for diabetes, reflecting average blood glucose levels over the past 2-3 months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard diagnostic criteria for diabetes include a fasting blood sugar (FBS) level greater than 126 mg/dl

 

Ref; Ghai Essential Paediatrics 10th Edition, Page No-546.

choices.text: Anti Myeloperoxidase antibody
Anti Thyroid peroxidase antibody
TSH receptor stimulating antibody
Anti DNAase antibody.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl visits the pediatric department with concerns about unexplained weight gain despite maintaining a low-calorie diet. She reports an inability to sustain physical activity with her peers due to rapid fatigue. Recently, she observed a swelling in her neck, prompting her visit. Given the described symptoms, which autoimmune antibody is most likely contributing to her current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anti Thyroid peroxidase antibody

 

The female is presenting with features of hypothyroidism, thyroid peroxidase antibody will be positive in case of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.

 

Features of hypothyroidism are:

 

Hypothyroidism symptoms may include:

 

  • Tiredness.
  • More sensitivity to cold.
  • Constipation.
  • Dry skin.
  • Weight gain.
  • Puffy face.
  • Hoarse voice.
  • Coarse hair and skin.
  • Muscle weakness.
  • Muscle aches, tenderness and stiffness.
  • Menstrual cycles that are heavier than usual or irregular.
  • Thinning hair.
  • Slowed heart rate, also called bradycardia.
  • Depression.

 

Treatment - Levothyroxine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anti Myeloperoxidase antibody: Typically associated with vasculitis (Wegener’s granulomatosis), such as microscopic polyangiitis, not directly related to thyroid function.

 

Option C. TSH receptor stimulating antibody: More commonly associated with Graves' disease, which typically presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, not weight gain and fatigue.

 

Option D. Anti DNAase antibody: Associated with a response to Streptococcal infections (SLE) and not directly linked to thyroid diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti Thyroid peroxidase (Anti-TPO) antibodies suggests autoimmune thyroiditis (Hashimoto's thyroiditis), which is consistent with the patient's symptoms of weight gain, fatigue, and neck swelling (due to thyroid gland enlargement). This condition often leads to hypothyroidism, where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland, reducing its ability to produce thyroid hormones.

 

Ref - Nelson 21st Edition Page No-2923.

choices.text: Nephropathy
Neuropathy
Coronary Artery disease
Retinopathy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with a 15-day history of polyuria and polydipsia. His mother notes that his clothes no longer fit him as they have become too loose. Laboratory tests reveal a random blood sugar (RBS) level of 320 mg/dl and low insulin levels, leading to a diagnosis of Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (DM). Considering the long-term complications of DM, which of the following is not considered a microvascular complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Coronary Artery disease.

 

Option C:

 

Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) is classified as a macrovascular, not a microvascular complication of diabetes. Macrovascular complications involve large blood vessels and include conditions like CAD, cerebrovascular disease, and peripheral artery disease. These complications are associated with the increased risk of heart attacks, strokes, and peripheral vascular disease in diabetic patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nephropathy: Diabetes can lead to damage to the small blood vessels in the kidneys, potentially causing chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease, which is a microvascular complication.

 

Option B. Neuropathy: High blood sugar levels can damage nerves throughout the body, leading to diabetic neuropathy, a common microvascular complication of diabetes.

 

Option D. Retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy involves damage to the small blood vessels in the retina, leading to vision problems and blindness, and is a microvascular complication of diabetes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Ghai Essential Paediatrics 8th Edition
